investigators: Zinke, J.; Pfeiffer, M.; Timm, O.; Dullo, W.-C.; Kroon, D.; Thomassin, B.A.
studyNotes:
Coupled Sr/Ca and d18O measurements from a coral at Mayotte (Comoros) 
used as a proxy for d18Oseawater and hydrological variability (P-E) 
in the western tropical Indian Ocean.

author.name: Zinke, J., M. Pfeiffer, O. Timm, W.-C. Dullo, D. Kroon, and B. A. Thomassin

publication.title: Mayotte coral reveals hydrological changes in the western Indian Ocean between 1881 and 1994
publication.citation:
Zinke, J., M. Pfeiffer, O. Timm, W.-C. Dullo, D. Kroon, and B. A. Thomassin. 2008.  
Mayotte coral reveals hydrological changes in the western Indian Ocean between 1881 and 1994. 
Geophys. Res. Lett., 35, L23707, doi:10.1029/2008GL035634.
publication.abstract:
We reconstruct the hydrologic history of the tropical
western Indian Ocean by calculating the d18Oseawater from
coupled coral Sr/Ca and d18O measurements in a massive
Porites coral from Mayotte (Comoros) between 1881 and
1994. We found that the precipitation-evaporation balance
varies naturally on time scales of 5-6 years and 18-25 years.
High (low) SSTs are associated with positive (negative)
d18Oseawater implying that atmospheric variability is linked
with remote climate modes in the Indian Ocean and the
tropical/extratropical Pacific Ocean. Warm El Nino-Southern
Oscillation events are associated with a negative freshwater
balance at Mayotte. This case study demonstrates that a
much denser network of d18Oseawater reconstructions is
crucial for understanding the spatial patterns of hydrological
conditions.

paleoData.dataTableNotes: Porites solida core; not named in paper
